title: (Canadian) Basic Qualifications Question Bank for Amateur Radio Operator Certificate Examination

test.question: Authority to make regulations governing radiocommunications is derived from:
test.A: A. the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service

test.question: Authority to make Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service is derived from:
test.D: D. the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service

test.question: The Department that is responsible for the administration of the Radiocommunication Act is:
test.B: B. Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada

test.question: The amateur radio service is defined in:
test.A: A. the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service

test.question: What must you do to notify your mailing address changes ?
test.A: A. Write amateur organizations advising them of your new address, enclosing your certificate
test.B: B. Contact Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada and provide details of your address change
test.C: C. Telephone your local club, and give them your new address
test.D: D. Contact an accredited examiner and provide details of your address change

test.question: An Amateur Radio Operator Certificate is valid for:
Whenever a change of address is made:
test.A: A. within the same province, there is no need to notify Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
test.B: B. Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada must be advised of any change in postal address
test.C: C. Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada must be notified within 14 days of operation at the new address
test.D: D. the station shall not be operated until a change of address card is forwarded to Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada

test.question: The Amateur Radio Operator Certificate:
test.A: A. must be kept on the person to whom it is issued
test.B: B. must be retained at the station
test.C: C. must be put on file
test.D: D. must be kept in a safe place

test.question: The holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate shall, at the request of a duly appointed radio inspector, produce the certificate, or a copy thereof, to the inspector, within ____ hours after the request:
The fee for an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate is:
The Amateur Radio Operator Certificate should be:
test.A: A. retained in a safety deposit box
test.B: B. retained on the radio amateur's person
test.C: C. retained in the radio amateur's vehicle
test.D: D. retained at the address provided to Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada

test.question: Out of amateur band transmissions:
test.A: A. are prohibited - penalties could be assessed to the control operator
test.B: B. must be identified with your call sign
test.D: D. are permitted for short tests only

test.question: If an amateur pretends there is an emergency and transmits the word MAYDAY, what is this called?
test.B: B. Nothing special: MAYDAY has no meaning in an emergency
test.D: D. A traditional greeting in May

test.question: A person found guilty of transmitting a false or fraudulent distress signal, or interfering with, or obstructing any radio communication, without lawful cause, may be liable, on summary conviction, to a penalty of:
test.B: B. a fine, not exceeding $5 000, or a prison term of one year, or both
test.D: D. a prison term of two years

test.question: What government document states the offences and penalties for non compliance of the rules governing radiocommunications?
test.A: A. The Official Radio Rules of Canada
test.C: C. The Radiocommunications Law Reform Act of 2002

test.question: Which of the following is not correct? The Minister may suspend an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate:
test.A: A. Where the holder has failed to comply with a request to pay fees or interest due
test.B: B. With no notice, or opportunity to make representation thereto
test.C: C. Where the holder has contravened the Radiocommunication Act, its Regulations, or the terms and conditions of the certificate
test.D: D. Where the certificate was obtained through misrepresentation

test.question: Which of the following statements is not correct?
test.A: A. A radio inspector may enter a dwelling without the consent of the occupant and without a warrant
test.B: B. Where entry is refused, and is necessary to perform his duties under the Act, a radio inspector may obtain a warrant
test.C: C. In executing a warrant, a radio inspector shall not use force, unless accompanied by a peace officer, and force is authorized
test.D: D. The person in charge of a place entered by a radio inspector shall give the inspector information that the inspector requests

test.question: What age must you be to hold an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic Qualification?
test.A: A. There are no age limits

test.question: Which examination must be passed before an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate is issued?
Holders of which one of the following certificates may be issued an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate?
test.A: A. Canadian Restricted Operator's Certificate - Maritime Commercial (ROCMC)
test.C: C. Canadian Radiocommunication Operator General Certificate Maritime (RGMC)

test.question: After an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic qualifications is issued, the holder may be examined for additional qualifications in the following order:
test.A: A. Morse code after passing the Basic with Honours
test.B: B. Advanced after passing Morse code
test.D: D. Morse code after passing the Advanced

test.question: One Morse code qualification is available for the Amateur Radio Operator Certificate. It is:
The holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with the Basic Qualification is authorized to operate following stations:
test.A: A. any authorized station except stations authorized in the amateur, aeronautical or maritime services
test.B: B. a station authorized in the amateur service
test.C: C. a station authorized in the aeronautical service
test.D: D. a station authorized in the maritime service

test.question: What conditions must candidates to amateur radio certification meet?
test.A: A. Be a Canadian citizen or permanent resident
test.B: B. Be at least 14 years of age and a Canadian citizen or permanent resident
test.C: C. Have a valid address in Canada

test.question: Radio apparatus may be installed, placed in operation, repaired or maintained by the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Advanced Qualification on behalf of another person:
test.A: A. if the other person is the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate to operate in the amateur radio service
test.B: B. pending the granting of a radio authorization, if the apparatus covers the amateur and commercial frequency bands
test.C: C. pending the granting of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate if the apparatus covers the amateur frequency bands only
test.D: D. if the transmitter of a station, for which a radio authorization is to be applied for, is type approved and crystal controlled

test.question: The holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate may design and build from scratch transmitting equipment for use in the amateur radio service provided that person has the:
test.C: C. Basic and Morse code qualification
test.D: D. Morse code with Honours qualification

test.question: Where a friend is not the holder of any type of radio operator certificate, you, as a holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic Qualification, may, on behalf of your friend:
test.A: A. install an amateur station, but not operate or permit the operation of the apparatus
test.B: B. install and operate the radio apparatus, using your own call sign
test.C: C. modify and repair the radio apparatus but not install it
test.D: D. not install, place in operation, modify, repair, maintain, or permit the operation of the radio apparatus

test.question: A radio amateur with Basic and Morse code qualifications may install an amateur station for another person:
test.A: A. only if the other person is the holder of a valid Amateur Radio Operator Certificate
test.B: B. only if the final power input does not exceed 100 watts
test.C: C. only if the station is for use on one of the VHF bands
test.D: D. only if the DC power input to the final stage does not exceed 200 watts

test.question: An amateur radio station with a maximum input power to the final stage of 2 watts:
test.A: A. is exempt from regulatory control by Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
test.B: B. must be operated by a person with an Amateur Certificate and call sign
test.C: C. must be licensed by Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
test.D: D. need not be licensed in isolated areas only

test.question: An amateur station may be used to communicate with:
test.A: A. stations operated under similar authorizations
test.B: B. any stations which are identified for special contests
test.C: C. armed forces stations during special contests and training exercises
test.D: D. any station transmitting in the amateur bands

test.question: Which of the following statements is not correct?
test.A: A. A radio amateur may use a linear amplifier to amplify the output of a licence-exempt transmitter outside any amateur radio allocations
test.B: B. A considerate operator does not transmit unnecessary signals
test.C: C. A courteous operator refrains from using offensive language
test.D: D. A radio amateur may not operate, or permit to be operated, a radio apparatus which he knows is not performing to the Radiocommunication Regulations

test.question: Which of the following statements is not correct?
test.A: A. A person may operate an amateur radio station when the person complies with the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service
test.B: B. An amateur radio operator transmitting unnecessary or offensive signals does not violate accepted practice
test.C: C. Except for a certified radio amateur operating within authorized amateur radio allocations, no person shall possess or operate any device for the purpose of amplifying the output power of a licenceexempt radio apparatus DA person may operate or permit the operation of radio apparatus only where the apparatus is maintained to the Radiocommunication Regulations tolerances

test.question: Which of the following statements is not correct? A person may operate radio apparatus, authorized in the amateur service:
test.A: A. on aeronautical, marine or land mobile frequencies
test.B: B. only where the person complies with the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service
test.C: C. only where the apparatus is maintained within the performance standards set by Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada regulations and policies
test.D: D. except for the amplification of the output power of licence-exempt radio apparatus operating outside authorized amateur radio service allocations

test.question: Some VHF and UHF FM radios purchased for use in the amateur service can also be programmed to communicate on frequencies used for the land mobile service. Under what conditions is this permissible?
test.A: A. The equipment is used in remote areas north of 60 degrees latitude
test.B: B. The radio is certified under the proper Radio Standard Specification for use in Canada and licensed by Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada on the specified frequencies
test.C: C. The radio operator has a Restricted Operator's Certificate
test.D: D. The equipment has a RF power output of 2 watts or less

test.question: Which of the following cannot be discussed on an amateur club net?
When is a radio amateur allowed to broadcast information to the general public?
test.A: A. Only when the operator is being paid
test.B: B. Only when broadcasts last less than 1 hour
test.C: C. Only when broadcasts last longer than 15 minutes

test.question: When may false or deceptive amateur signals or communications be transmitted?
test.B: B. When operating a beacon transmitter in a fox hunt exercise
test.C: C. When playing a harmless practical joke
test.D: D. When you need to hide the meaning of a message for secrecy

test.question: Which of the following one-way communications may not be transmitted in the amateur service?
test.B: B. Broadcasts intended for the general public
test.C: C. Radio control commands to model craft
test.D: D. Brief transmissions to make adjustments to the station

test.question: You wish to develop and use a new digital encoding technique to transmit data over amateur radio spectrum. Under what conditions is this permissible?
test.A: A. When it includes sending the amateur station's call sign
test.B: B. When the encoding technique is published in the public domain
test.C: C. When it is used for music streaming content DWhen it is used for commercial traffic

test.question: When may an amateur station in two-way communication transmit an encoded message?
test.A: A. Only when the encoding or cipher is not secret
test.B: B. During a declared communications emergency

test.question: What are the restrictions on the use of abbreviations or procedural signals in the amateur service?
test.B: B. They are not permitted because they obscure the meaning of a message to government monitoring stations
test.D: D. They may be used if the signals or codes are not secret

test.question: What should you do to keep you station from retransmitting music or signals from a non-amateur station?
test.A: A. Adjust your transceiver noise blanker
test.B: B. Turn down the volume of background audio
test.C: C. Turn up the volume of your transmitter
test.D: D. Speak closer to the microphone to increase your signal strength

test.question: The transmission of a secret code by the operator of an amateur station:
test.C: C. must be approved by Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
test.D: D. is permitted for third-party traffic

test.question: A radio amateur may be engaged in communication which include the transmission of:
test.A: A. programming that originates from a broadcasting undertaking
test.B: B. radiocommunication in support of industrial, business, or professional activities

test.question: In the amateur radio service, business communications:
test.A: A. are permitted on some bands
test.B: B. are only permitted if they are for the safety of life or immediate protection of property
test.C: C. are not prohibited by regulation
test.D: D. are not permitted under any circumstance

test.question: Where may the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate operate an amateur radio station in Canada?
test.B: B. Anywhere in Canada during times of emergency
test.C: C. Only at the address shown on Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada records
test.D: D. Anywhere in your call sign prefix area

test.question: Which type of station may transmit one-way communications?
Amateur radio operators may install or operate radio apparatus:
test.A: A. at the address which is on record at Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada and in two mobiles
test.B: B. at any location in Canada
test.C: C. only at the address which is on record at Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
test.D: D. at the address which is on record at Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada and at one other location

test.question: In order to install any radio apparatus, to be used specifically for receiving and automatically retransmitting radiotelephone communications within the same frequency band, a radio amateur must hold an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate, with a minimum of:
test.C: C. Basic and Morse code qualifications

test.question: In order to install any radio apparatus, to be used specifically for an amateur radio club station, the radio amateur must hold an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate, with a minimum of the following qualifications:
test.D: D. Basic, Advanced and Morse code

test.question: In order to install or operate a transmitter or RF amplifier that is neither professionally designed nor commercially manufactured for use in the amateur service, a radio amateur must hold an Amateur Operator's Certificate, with a minimum of which qualifications?
test.D: D. Basic, Advanced and Morse code

test.question: Who is responsible for the proper operation of an amateur station?
test.A: A. Only the station owner who is the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate
test.B: B. The person who owns the station equipment
test.D: D. Both the control operator and the station owner

test.question: If you transmit from another amateur's station, who is responsible for its proper operation?
test.D: D. The station owner, unless the station records show that you were the control operator at the time

test.question: What is your responsibility as a station owner?
test.A: A. You must be present whenever the station is operated
test.B: B. You must notify Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada if another amateur acts as the control operator
test.C: C. You are responsible for the proper operation of the station in accordance with the regulations
test.D: D. You must allow another amateur to operate your station upon request

test.question: Who may be the control operator of an amateur station?
test.A: A. Any person over 21 years of age
test.B: B. Any qualified amateur chosen by the station owner
test.C: C. Any person over 21 years of age with a Basic Qualification DAny person over 21 years of age with Basic and Morse code qualifications

test.question: When must an amateur station have a control operator?
test.A: A. Whenever the station is transmitting
test.B: B. A control operator is not needed
test.C: C. Whenever the station receiver is operated
test.D: D. Only when training another amateur

test.question: When an amateur station is transmitting, where must its control operator be?
test.A: A. At the station's control point
test.B: B. Anywhere in the same building as the transmitter
test.C: C. At the station's entrance, to control entry to the room
test.D: D. Anywhere within 50 km of the station location

test.question: Why can't family members without qualifications transmit using your amateur station if they are alone with your equipment?
test.A: A. They must first know how to use the right abbreviations and Q signals
test.B: B. They must first know the right frequencies and emission modes for transmitting
test.C: C. They must hold suitable amateur radio qualifications before they are allowed to be control operators
test.D: D. They must not use your equipment without your permission

test.question: The owner of an amateur station may:
test.A: A. permit anyone to use the station without restrictions
test.B: B. permit anyone to use the station and take part in communications
test.C: C. permit any person to operate the station under the supervision and in the presence of the holder of the amateur operator certificate
test.D: D. permit anyone to take part in communications only if prior written permission is received from Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada

test.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
test.A: A. Any person may operate an amateur station under supervision, and in the presence of, a person holding appropriate qualifications
test.B: B. A person, holding only Basic Qualification, may operate another station on 14.2 MHz
test.C: C. Radio amateurs may permit any person to operate the station without supervision
test.D: D. Any person may operate a station in the amateur radio service

test.question: What is a transmission called that disturbs other communications?
When may you deliberately interfere with another station's communications?
test.C: C. Only if the station is operating illegally
test.D: D. Only if the station begins transmitting on

test.question: If the regulations say that the amateur service is a secondary user of a frequency band, and another service is a primary user, what does this mean?
test.A: A. Nothing special: all users of a frequency band have equal rights to operate
test.B: B. Amateurs are only allowed to use the frequency band during emergencies
test.C: C. Amateurs must increase transmitter power to overcome any interference caused by primary users DAmateurs are allowed to use the frequency band only if they do not cause interference to primary users

test.question: What rule applies if two amateurs want to use the same frequency?
test.A: A. The station operator with a lesser qualification must yield the frequency to an operator of higher qualification
test.B: B. The station operator with a lower power output must yield the frequency to the station with a higher power output
test.C: C. Station operators in ITU Regions 1 and 3 must yield the frequency to stations in ITU Region 2
test.D: D. Both station operators have an equal right to operate on the frequency

test.question: What name is given to a form of interference that seriously degrades, obstructs or repeatedly interrupts a radiocommunication service?
Where interference to the reception of radiocommunications is caused by the operation of an amateur station:
test.A: A. the amateur station operator may continue to operate without restrictions
test.B: B. the amateur station operator may continue to operate and the necessary steps can be taken when the amateur operator can afford it
test.C: C. the Minister may require that the necessary steps for the prevention of the interference be taken by the radio amateur
test.D: D. the amateur station operator is not obligated to take any action

test.question: Radio amateur operation must not cause interference to other radio services operating in which of the following bands?
Radio amateur operations are not ARE NOT protected from interference caused by another service operating in which of the following frequency bands?
Which of the following is not correct? The operator of an amateur station:
test.A: A. may make trials or tests, even though there is a possibility of interfering with other stations
test.B: B. shall not cause harmful interference to a station in another service which has primary use of that band
test.C: C. may conduct technical experiments using the station apparatus
test.D: D. may make trials or tests, except if there is a possibility of interference to other stations

test.question: Which of these amateur bands may be heavily occupied by licence exempt devices?
The amateur radio service is authorized to share a portion of what Industrial Scientific Medical (ISM) band that is heavily used by licence exempt devices?
Amateur radio stations may communicate:
test.A: A. with anyone who uses international Morse code
test.C: C. with any station involved in a real or simulated emergency
test.D: D. only with other amateur stations

test.question: During relief operations in the days following a disaster, when may an amateur use his equipment to communicate on frequencies outside amateur bands?
test.B: B. When relaying messages on behalf of government agencies
test.C: C. When messages are destined to agencies without amateur radio support
test.D: D. When normal communication systems are overloaded, damaged or disrupted

test.question: If you hear an unanswered distress signal on an amateur band where you do not have privileges to communicate:
test.A: A. you may offer assistance after contacting Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada for permission to do so
test.B: B. you may not offer assistance
test.D: D. you may offer assistance using international Morse code only

test.question: In the amateur radio service, it is permissible to broadcast:
test.C: C. programming that originates from a broadcast undertaking
test.D: D. radio communications required for the immediate safety of life of individuals or the immediate protection of property

test.question: An amateur radio station in distress may:
test.A: A. use any means of radiocommunication, but only on internationally recognized emergency channels
test.B: B. only Morse code communications on internationally recognized emergency channels
test.D: D. only use radiocommunication bands for which the operator is qualified to use

test.question: During a disaster, when may an amateur station make transmissions necessary to meet essential communication needs and assist relief operations?
test.A: A. Only when the local emergency net is activated
test.B: B. When normal communication systems are overloaded, damaged or disrupted
test.C: C. Never: only official emergency stations may transmit in a disaster
test.D: D. When normal communication systems are working but are not convenient

test.question: During an emergency, what power output limitations must be observed by a station in distress?
test.A: A. There are no limitations for a station in distress
test.B: B. 1000 watts PEP during daylight hours, reduced to 200 watts PEP during the night
test.C: C. 1500 watts PEP D200 watts PEP

test.question: During a disaster:
test.A: A. use only frequencies in the 80 metre band
test.B: B. use only frequencies in the 40 metre band
test.C: C. use any United Nations approved frequency
test.D: D. most communications are handled by nets using predetermined frequencies in amateur bands. Operators not directly involved with disaster communications are requested to avoid making unnecessary transmissions on or near frequencies being used for disaster communications

test.question: Messages from recognized public service agencies may be handled by amateur radio stations:
test.A: A. during peace time and civil emergencies and exercises
test.C: C. when Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada has issued a special authorization
test.D: D. only on the 7 and 14 MHz bands

test.question: It is permissible to interfere with the working of another station if:
test.A: A. the other station is not operating according to the Radiocommunication Regulations
test.B: B. you both wish to contact the same station
test.C: C. the other station is interfering with your transmission
test.D: D. your station is directly involved with a distress situation

test.question: What kind of payment is allowed for third-party messages sent by an amateur station?
test.C: C. Any amount agreed upon in advance
test.D: D. No payment of any kind is allowed

test.question: Radiocommunications transmitted by stations other than a broadcasting station may be divulged or used:
test.A: A. if transmitted in English or French
test.C: C. if it is transmitted by an amateur station
test.D: D. if transmitted by any station using the international Morse code

test.question: The operator of an amateur station:
test.A: A. may accept a gift or gratuity in lieu of remuneration for any message that the person transmits or receives
test.B: B. shall not demand or accept remuneration in any form, in respect of a radiocommunication that the person transmits or receives
test.C: C. shall charge no less than $10 for each message that the person transmits or receives
test.D: D. shall charge no more than $10 for each message that the person transmits or receives

test.question: Which of the following is not an exception from the penalties under the Act, for divulging, intercepting or using information obtained through radiocommunication, other than broadcasting?
test.A: A. Where it is to provide information for a journalist
test.B: B. Where it is for the purpose of preserving or protecting property, or for the prevention of harm to a person
test.C: C. Where it is for the purpose of giving evidence in a criminal or civil proceeding in which persons are required to give evidence
test.D: D. Where it is on behalf of Canada, for the purpose of international or national defence or security

test.question: Which of the following call signs is a valid Canadian amateur radio call sign?
How often must an amateur station be identified?
test.A: A. At least every thirty minutes, and at the beginning and at the end of a contact
test.B: B. At the beginning of a contact and at least every thirty minutes after that
test.C: C. At least once during each transmission
test.D: D. At the beginning and end of each transmission

test.question: What do you transmit to identify your amateur station?
test.A: A. Your first name and your location

test.question: What identification, if any, is required when two amateur stations begin communications?
test.A: A. One of the stations must give both stations' call signs
test.B: B. Each station must transmit its own call sign
test.D: D. Both stations must transmit both call signs

test.question: What identification, if any, is required when two amateur stations end communications?
test.A: A. Both stations must transmit both call signs
test.B: B. Each station must transmit its own call sign
test.D: D. One of the stations must transmit both stations' call signs

test.question: What is the longest period of time an amateur station can transmit, without identifying by call sign?
When may an amateur transmit unidentified communications?
test.A: A. Never, except to control a model craft
test.B: B. Only for brief tests not meant as messages
test.C: C. Only if it does not interfere with others
test.D: D. Only for two-way or third-party communications

test.question: What language may you use when identifying your station?
test.B: B. Any language being used for a contact
test.C: C. Any language being used for a contact, providing Canada has a third-party communications agreement with that country
test.D: D. Any language of a country which is a member of the International Telecommunication Union

test.question: The call sign of an amateur station must be transmitted:
test.A: A. at the beginning and at the end of each exchange of communications and at intervals not greater than 30 minutes
test.B: B. at intervals not greater than three minutes when using voice communications
test.C: C. at intervals not greater than ten minutes when using Morse code
test.D: D. when requested to do so by the station being called

test.question: The call sign of an amateur station must be sent:
test.C: C. once after initial contact Dat the beginning and end of each exchange of communications, and at least every 30 minutes, while in communications

test.question: The call sign of a Canadian amateur radio station would normally start with the letters:
test.A: A. A, K, N or W
test.B: B. EA, EI, RO or UY
test.C: C. VA, VE, VO or VY
test.D: D. GA, GE, MO or VQ

test.question: If a non-amateur friend is using your station to talk to someone in Canada, and a foreign station breaks in to talk to your friend, what should you do?
test.A: A. Stop all discussions and quickly sign off
test.B: B. Have your friend wait until you determine from the foreign station if their administration permits third-party traffic
test.C: C. Since you can talk to foreign amateurs, your friend may keep talking as long as you are the control operator
test.D: D. Report the incident to the foreign amateur's government

test.question: If you let an unqualified third party use your amateur station, what must you do at your station's control point?
test.A: A. You must continuously monitor and supervise the third party's participation
test.B: B. You must key the transmitter and make the station identification
test.C: C. You must monitor and supervise the communication only if contacts are made on frequencies below 30 MHz
test.D: D. You must monitor and supervise the communication only if contacts are made in countries which have no third party communications

test.question: Radio amateurs may use their stations to transmit international communications on behalf of a third party only if:
test.A: A. the amateur station has received written authorization from Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada to pass third party traffic
test.B: B. the communication is transmitted by secret code
test.C: C. prior remuneration has been received
test.D: D. such communications have been authorized by the other country concerned

test.question: A person operating a Canadian amateur station is forbidden to communicate with amateur stations of another country:
test.A: A. unless he is passing third-party traffic
test.B: B. when that country has notified the International Telecommunication Union that it objects to such communications
test.C: C. without written permission from Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
test.D: D. until he has properly identified his station

test.question: International communications on behalf of third parties may be transmitted by an amateur station only if:
test.B: B. the countries concerned have authorized such communications
test.C: C. English or French is used to identify the station at the end of each transmission
test.D: D. the countries for which the traffic is intended have registered their consent to such communications with the ITU

test.question: Amateur third party communications is:
test.A: A. the transmission of commercial or secret messages
test.B: B. a simultaneous communication between three operators
test.D: D. the transmission of non-commercial or personal messages to or on behalf of a third party

test.question: International third party amateur radio communication in case of emergencies or disaster relief is expressly permitted unless:
test.A: A. the foreign administration is in a declared state of war
test.B: B. internet service is working well in the foreign country involved
test.C: C. specifically prohibited by the foreign administration concerned Dsatellite communication can be originated in the disaster area

test.question: One of the following is not considered to be communications on behalf of a third party, even though the message is originated by, or addressed to, a non-amateur:
test.A: A. all messages received from Canadian stations
test.B: B. messages originated from Canadian Forces Affiliate Radio Service (CFARS)
test.C: C. messages that are handled within a local network
test.D: D. messages addressed to points within Canada

test.question: One of the following is not considered to be communications on behalf of a third party, even though the message may be originated by, or addressed to, a non-amateur:
test.A: A. messages that originate from the United States Military Auxiliary Radio System (MARS)
test.B: B. all messages originated by Canadian amateur stations
test.C: C. messages addressed to points within Canada from the United States
test.D: D. messages that are handled within local networks during a simulated emergency exercise

test.question: Which of the following is not correct? While operating in Canada a radio amateur licensed by the Government of the United States must:
test.A: A. qualify his identification when operating phone by adding to the call sign the word mobile or portable or when operating Morse code by adding a slash /
